metadata.title: In Situ Polymerization of Aniline on Morphology-Controlled Ultrafine Manganese Oxyhydroxide for High-Performance Electrochemical Sensing Applications

sections.text:
H336 Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 166 (8) H336-H342 (2019) 0013-4651/2019/166(8)/H336/7/$38.00 © The Electrochemical Society
In Situ Polymerization of Aniline on Morphology-Controlled Ultrafine Manganese Oxyhydroxide for High-Performance Electrochemical Sensing Applications Wushuang Bai, 1 Xinjin Zhang,2 and Jianbin Zheng 2,z
1College of Food Science and Engineering, Shaanxi Provincial Key Laboratory of Electroanalytical Chemistry, Northwest University, Xi’an, Shaanxi 710069, People’s Republic of China 2College of Chemistry & Materials Science, Key Laboratory of Synthetic and Natural Functional Molecule Chemistry of the Ministry of Education, Shaanxi Provincial Key Laboratory of Electroanalytical Chemistry, Northwest University, Xi’an, Shaanxi 710069, People’s Republic of China
The controllable synthesis of manganese oxyhydroxide (MnOOH) nanomaterials was achieved via a simple solvothermal reaction in the presence of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) and sodium dodecyl benzene sulfonate. The obtained MnOOH nanowires, nanonets, and nanorods were all used for the in-situ polymerization of aniline to afford three types of polyaniline (PANI)/MnOOH composites: PANI/w-MnOOH, PANI/n-MnOOH, and PANI/r-MnOOH. The obtained PANI/MnOOH composites were tested as catalysts for the electrochemical oxidation of dopamine (DA), with PANI/n-MnOOH demonstrating the best catalytic activity. PANI/n-MnOOH was then used for fabricating a DA electrochemical sensor, which exhibited an ultra-sensitive detection limit of 0.01 μM and a broad linear range of 0.05–2.78 mM. Finally, PANI/n-MnOOH was used as a substrate for the adsorption of gold nanoparticles (AuNPs). The obtained AuNPs/PANI/n-MnOOH composite was applied for fabricating an ascorbic acid (AA) electrochemical sensor, which exhibited a low detection limit of 0.1 μM and a broad linear range of 0.3–77.8 mM. This work provides a platform for the controllable synthesis of manganese oxides (MnOx), conducting polymers, and metal materials for electrochemical sensing and catalytic applications. © 2019 The Electrochemical Society. [DOI: 10.1149/2.1101908jes]
Manuscript submitted March 7, 2019; revised manuscript received April 15, 2019. Published May 14, 2019.
In recent years, metal oxide nanomaterials have demonstrated great potential in the fields of catalysis and energy storage.1–3 Therefore, developing new strategies to construct metal oxide nanomaterials with controlled structures and morphologies has been a subject of great interest.4–6 Among the various metal oxide materials, manganese oxides (MnOx), which are transition-metal oxides, have been widely used for their low cost, diverse structures, low toxicity, high theoretical capacitance, and catalytic properties.7–11 Therefore, researches have focused their efforts on the synthesis and applications of MnOx, such as MnO2 and Mn3O4. Despite advances in this area of research, few reports investigate the development of manganese oxyhydroxide (MnOOH) materials. Similar to MnO2 and Mn3O4, MnOOH exhibits excellent catalytic, electronic, and electrochemical properties, which can be used for catalysis, capacitors, and lithium battery applications. Additionally, MnOOH is an important precursor in the synthesis of other MnOx.12–18 For example, Smith et al.12 synthesized MnOOH nanomaterials to investigate the coordination geometry and oxidation state requirements of corner-sharing MnO6 octahedra. In their study, MnOOH nanomaterials exhibited good catalytic activity for water oxidations. MnOOH nanowires with high aspect ratios were synthesized by Zhang and co-workers through a simple onestep hydrothermal method.13 The materials were used for fabricating rechargeable nonaqueous lithium-oxygen batteries. Cao et al.14 synthesized MnOOH/GO nanocomposites via a one-pot method based on solvothermal reactions, which were used for asymmetric supercapacitors. Xu et al.15 fabricated a high-performance hydrogen peroxide electrochemical sensor based on MnOOH nanorod arrays. Taken together, these previous reports demonstrate the great potential of MnOOH materials in catalysis and energy conversion systems. Therefore, developing methods for the controlled synthesis of well-defined MnOOH nanomaterials is of great importance in the field of materials research. In the present work, the controllable synthesis of MnOOH nanomaterials was realized based on a simple solvothermal reaction. The utility of the resulting MnOOH nanomaterials (nanowires, nanonets, and nanorods) were demonstrated in electrochemical sensing applications.
Despite recent progress in MnOOH synthesis, it is still necessary to improve the conductivity of MnOOH-based materials. The conducting polymer polyaniline (PANI) has received attention for its high conductivity, ease of preparation, and good environmental
zE-mail: zhengjb@nwu.edu.cn
stability.19–21 PANI has been widely used in electrochromic devices, secondary batteries, catalysis, and for electrostatic discharge protection. PANI-based nanocomposites, which are prepared by in-situ polymerization techniques on substrate surfaces, have been used for various applications, especially electrochemical catalytic sensing.22–24 Given the high conductivity and large surface area of this polymer, composites incorporating PANI structures would likely have improved conducting and adsorption properties. In this work, MnOOH materials of three distinct morphologies (nanowires, nanonets, and nanorods) were used as substrates for the in-situ polymerization of aniline, resulting in three distinct nanocomposites: PANI/w-MnOOH, PANI/n-MnOOH, and PANI/r-MnOOH. Then, the three nanocomposites were used as catalysts for the electrochemical oxidation of dopamine (DA). Among the three types of nanocomposites, PANI/nMnOOH exhibited the best catalytic activity and, then, was used to fabricate a DA electrochemical sensor. The detection mechanism has been shown in Scheme 1a, DA will be electrochemical oxidized to odopaminoquinone by PANI/n-MnOOH nanowires under suitable potential. Actually, o-dopaminoquinone will be electro-reduced back to DA. However, in this work, only oxidation current will be used for detection.
It has been demonstrated that certain metal particles such as silver (Ag), copper (Cu), or gold (Au) can be adsorbed by PANI easily.25–27 Therefore, the synthesized PANI/n-MnOOH structure was used to adsorb Au nanoparticles (NPs), affording the AuNPs/PANI/n-MnOOH nanocomposite. Given the unique electrical and optical properties and
Scheme 1. Electrochemical sensing detection mechanism of DA (a) and AA (b).
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 132.174.251.90Downloaded on 2019-07-20 to IP
extensive applications of Au nanomaterials,28–30 the AuNPs/PANI/nMnOOH nanocomposite was then used for fabricating an ascorbic acid (AA) electrochemical sensor. The detection mechanism has been shown in Scheme 1b, which is similar as DA. The combined work focuses on developing a platform for the controllable synthesis of MnOx, conducting polymers, and metal nanomaterials and their application in high-performance electrochemical sensors.

sections.heading: Experimental
sections.text:
Chemicals and reagents.—Sodium dodecyl benzene sulfonate (SDBS, AR), ammonium persulfate (APS, AR), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, Mw = 55,000), manganese nitrate (Mn(NO3)2·6H2O, AR) and potassium permanganate (KMnO4, AR) were all purchased from Tianli Chemistry Reagent Co., Ltd, China. Aniline (ACS, >99.0%), dopamine (DA, AR), ascorbic acid (AA, AR), chloroauric acid (HAuCl4·4H2O) and trisodium citrate (AR) were all purchased from Sigma Chemical Co. All the reagents were of analytical reagent grade and ultrapure water was used throughout all experiments (Purified by Millipore system).
Apparatus.—Field emission electron microscopic (FESEM) was carried out on a scanning electron microscope (SU8020 HITACHI Japan). Field emission transmission electron microscopic (FETEM) images were carried out by Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN (FEI, USA). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were observed by D/MAX3C (Rigaku Japan). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was recorded with TENSIR 27 (Bruker, German). CHI 660 electrochemical workstation (Shanghai CH Instrument Co. Ltd., China).
Preparation of MnOOH nanomaterial.—0.5 g SDBS and 0.3 g PVP were dissolved in 30 mL water under continuous stirring until the solution was clarified. 1.2 mL of 0.5 M Mn(NO3)2·6H2O and 2 mL of 0.2 M KMnO4 were added slowly to the above solution under continuous stirring, respectively. At last, the mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and the reaction was performed under 180°C for 3.5 h, and then cooled down to room temperature. The precipitates were separated by centrifugation and washed three times by water and absolute ethanol, followed by vacuum drying at 70°C.
Preparation of PANI/MnOOH nancomposite.—The PANI/MnOOH nanocomposites were synthesized by one-step in situ polymerization of aniline. 100 mg of MnOOH was dispersed in 30 mL water under sonication for 30 min. Then 0.5 mL aniline was added to the above suspension under stirring for 30min. At last, 1 M HCl containing 0.45 g APS was added drop by drop under stirring and the reaction was performed overnight. The precipitates were separated by centrifugation and washed three times by water and absolute ethanol, followed by vacuum drying at 70°C.
Preparation of Au NPs/PANI/MnOOH nancomposite.—Au NPs were synthesized first. It was prepared according to the previous
report.31 In brief, HAuCl4 aqueous solution was boiled and treated with trisodium citrate under reflux. The obtained Au colloid was wine red.
Then PANI/MnOOH nanocomposites were dispersed in 30 mL water solution under sonication for 30 min. 50 mL Au colloid were added slowly under stirring. The reaction was allowed to proceed for 12 h. The precipitates were separated by centrifugation and washed three times by water and absolute ethanol, followed by vacuum drying at 70°C.
Preparation of modified electrode.—The preparation method has been used in our previous work,32 the experimental steps have been added in supporting information. The modified electrodes can be expressed as MnOOH/GCE, PANI/MnOOH/GCE and Au NPs/PANI/MnOOH/GCE.

sections.heading: Results and Discussion
sections.text:
Morphology and structural characterization of MnOOH, PANI/MnOOH, and AuNPs/PANI/n-MnOOH.—Figure 1 depicts scanning electron microscopy (SEM) patterns of MnOOH nanomaterials. The obtained MnOOH nanomaterial exhibits a net-like structure which is composed of thin wires and thick rods (Figure 1A). The diameters of the nanowires and nanorods are approximately 10 and 200 nm, respectively, with a length of several micrometers (Figures 1B and 1C). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of MnOOH characterize the material as monoclinic (manganite, space group P21/c(14), JCPDS No. 88-0649), and no other crystalline phases could be identified (Figure 2A). These XRD data demonstrate that there is no detectable impurity in the product. The FT-IR spectrum of MnOOH reveals a peak at 642 cm−1, which is attributed to the Mn-O bond vibrations in MnOOH (Figure 2C). The three peaks located at 1053, 1108, and 1178 cm−1 are attributed to –OH bending modes. The two peaks located at 1653 and 2360 cm−1 are consistent with traces of water and carbon dioxide, which may be due to the high surface-to-volume ratio of the MnOOH nanonets. The growth mechanism of MnOOH nanonets have been extensively studied,33 and a detailed analysis is provided in the supplementary material. The growth of the net structure was obtained after 3–4 h (Figure S1).
The morphology-controlled synthesis of MnOOH was realized by systematic modification of the experimental temperature. SEM patterns of the MnOOH materials synthesized at different temperatures for 3.5 h are shown in Figure 3 (A at room temperature, B at 70°C, C at 150°C, D at 180°C, E at 200°C, F at 220°C). Pure, ultrafine nanowires were obtained at room temperature (Figure 3A). The wires exhibit a diameter of 10-20 nm and a length of several micrometers. Figures 3B and 3C show the morphology of the obtained products, which were prepared at 70 and 150°C, respectively. The two materials exhibited similar morphology to the nanowires in Figure 3A; however, particles and sheets were detected in Figures 3B and 3C, respectively. When the temperature was increased to 180°C, nanomaterials with a net-like structure were obtained (Figure 3D). When the temperature was increased to 220°C, pure nanorods with a uniform diameter of about
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 132.174.251.90Downloaded on 2019-07-20 to IP
200 nm were synthesized (Figure 3F). The products in Figures 3B and 3C are consistent with materials transitioning from nanowires to nanonets, and the product in Figure 3E has features that suggest a transition from nanonets to nanorods. The XRD patterns of MnOOH prepared at different experimental temperatures are depicted in Figure 2A (a at room temperature, b at 70°C, c at 150°C, d at 180°C, e at 220°C). When the reaction temperature was increased, the diffraction peak intensity of MnOOH increased, and more characteristic peaks of MnOOH could be detected in the spectra. As demonstrated in our previous work,34 higher temperatures can provide more energy and promote the oriented growth of MnOOH nuclei. Therefore, the crystallization of MnOOH is more complete at elevated temperatures, leading to more characteristic peaks and higher peak intensities. Accordingly, the morphology-controlled synthesis of MnOOH was realized by judicious choice of temperature to access three distinct MnOOH nanomaterials: nanowires, nanonets, and nanorods.
The three types of synthesized MnOOH were all used for preparing PANI/MnOOH nanocomposites. The PANI/MnOOH nanowires (PANI/w-MnOOH), nanonets (PANI/n-MnOOH), and nanorods (PANI/r-MnOOH) were synthesized according to a procedure in the supplementary information. Figures 4A and 4B show the morphology of PANI/w-MnOOH. Compared to the MnOOH nanowires (Figure 3A), the obtained PANI/w-MnOOH exhibits similar wire
structures; however, compared to the smooth surface of the MnOOH wire, the surface of PANI/w-MnOOH is rough and has a larger diameter (∼30 vs. 5–10 nm). These unique features are attributed to adsorbed PANI. PANI/n-MnOOH (Figures 4C and 4D) exhibits a similar rough surface as PANI/n-MnOOH but has a larger diameter. The morphology of PANI/r-MnOOH (Figures 4E and 4F) is also rough and has a larger diameter (300 nm) than the corresponding MnOOH nanorod.
The FT-IR spectra of the two sets of materials were also compared. Various characteristic peaks of PANI were evident in the FT-IR spectra of the PANI/MnOOH composites (Figure 2C-b). For example, looking at the PANI/n-MnOOH spectrum, the peaks at 1487 and 1566 cm−1 can be attributed to C=C stretching of quinoid and benzenoid rings. The peaks at 1242 and 1300 cm−1 correspond to the C–N and C=N stretching modes, and the peaks at 1143 and 802 cm−1 are related to the in-and-out-of-plane bending vibrations of C–H. These data demonstrate the successful synthesis of the PANI/MnOOH composites.
Given the excellent catalytic activity of PANI/n-MnOOH and the favorable adsorption between PANI and Au nanoparticles, the use of PANI/n-MnOOH as a substrate to synthesize the AuNPs/PANI/nMnOOH nanocomposite was achieved next. Figure 5 shows the morphology of the obtained AuNPs/PANI/n-MnOOH nanocomposite. According to the SEM patterns (Figures 5A and 5B), AuNPs were assembled onto PANI/n-MnOOH without any aggregation; the AuNPs
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 132.174.251.90Downloaded on 2019-07-20 to IP
were dispersed uniformly on the surface of PANI/n-MnOOH, and the particles exhibited a homogeneous diameter of 15 nm (Figures 5C and 5D). The XRD patterns of the AuNPs/PANI/n-MnOOH nanocomposite show a broad peak with a 2θ value of 22°. This peak is attributed to the fluxional polymer chains of PANI. The three peaks located at approximately 38, 44, and 65 77° represent the (111), (200), and (220) Bragg reflections of the AuNPs, respectively. The FT-IR spectrum of AuNPs/PANI/n-MnOOH (Figure 2C-c) exhibits similar peaks to its PANI/n-MnOOH precursor, which is consistent with previous reports.
Electrochemical sensing application of PANI/MnOOH.—The obtained PANI/w-MnOOH, PANI/n-MnOOH, and PANI/r-MnOOH composites were used to fabricate the modified electrodes PANI/wMnOOH/GCE, PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE, and PANI/r-MnOOH/GCE, respectively (GCE = glassy carbon electrode). The electrocatalytic behaviors of the obtained materials with different morphologies were investigated by cyclic voltammetry (CV). Figure 6A shows the CV curves of GCE (a, a’) and MnOOH/GCE (b, b’) in the absence (a, b) and presence (a’, b’) of 1 mM of DA in 0.1 M phosphate-buffered
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 132.174.251.90Downloaded on 2019-07-20 to IP
saline (PBS) (pH = 7.2). As shown in the CV trace, GCE exhibits almost no electrochemical response in the absence of DA (Figure 6Aa). After 1 mM of DA was added, a pair of redox peaks appeared (Figure 6A-a’), and the oxidation peak current was detected at approximately 5 μA. MnOOH/GCE showed a higher current response than the GCE in the presence of 1 mM DA (Figure 6A-b’). Under these conditions, a pair of redox peaks were detected at 0 V and 0.3 V and the oxidation and reduction peak currents were identified at approximately 17 and 12 μA, respectively. However, compared to MnOOH/GCE, PANI/MnOOH/GCE exhibited the highest current response. Figure 6B shows the CV curves of PANI/MnOOH/GCE in the absence (c) and presence (c’) of 1 mM of DA. In the absence of DA, a pair of weak redox peaks appeared at approximately 0.15 and −0.15 V (Figure 6B-c). These peaks could be due to the redox behavior of PANI on the surface of the electrode, which would not influence catalytic activity.35,36 After 1 mM of DA was added, an oxidation peak appeared at 0.28 V with a current peak of approximately 50 μA. Compared to the GCE and MnOOH/GCE, PANI/MnOOH/GCE exhibited the best electrocatalytic performance in the oxidation of DA.
The CV curves of PANI/w-MnOOH/GCE (Figure 6C) and PANI/rMnOOH/GCE (Figure 6D) are depicted in the absence (a) and presence (b) of 1 mM of DA in 0.1 M PBS (pH = 7.2). In the presence of DA, PANI/w-MnOOH/GCE exhibited an oxidation current peak at 0.31 V with a peak height current of 30 μA (Figure 6C-a’), which is lower than that of PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE. In addition, PANI/rMnOOH/GCE exhibited the highest current response in the absence of DA (Figure 6D-a). After 1 mM of DA was added to this modified electrode system, the oxidation peak was generated at a higher potential (0.4 V) with a current height of approximately 50 μA (Figure 6Da’). Comparing all three composites (PANI/w-MnOOH/GCE, PANI/nMnOOH/GCE, and PANI/r-MnOOH/GCE), PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE exhibited the best catalytic activity for the electrooxidation of DA. This enhanced property may be due to the 3D net-like structure of n-MnOOH, which provides more active sites for DA oxidation.
CV analyses of PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE were also performed with different concentrations of DA (Figure 7A). The peak current of the modified electrode increased with higher concentrations of DA. Additionally, the relationship between the peak current and DA concentration was linear (Figure 7B). Figure 8C shows the amperometric response of PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE in 0.1 M PBS (pH = 7.2) at an initial potential of 0.3 V. The PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE system exhibited good current responses when different concentrations of DA were
added. Additionally, the modified electrode displayed a broad linear detection range of 0.05–2.78 mM (Figure 8D). The linear regression equation for this system was determined to be I(μA) = 1.06C(mM) + 0.099 with an estimated detection limit of 0.01 μM.
When comparing the prepared PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE with several reported DA electrochemical sensors (Table I), the current system demonstrates a relatively low detection limit and broad linear range. These attributes can be rationalized by the net-like structure of nMnOOH, which provides adequate space for aniline polymerization and, ultimately, a more active site for DA catalysis. Additionally, PANI increases the conductivity of the material and thus improves its electrocatalytic signal. Then, the stability and reproducibility of PANI/nMnOOH/GCE have been researched, and the results have been shown in Figure S2 and Table S1. It can be seen that the modified electrode exhibited good stability and reproducibility (Supporting information). At last, detection of DA was processed in the presence of AA (Figure S3 and S4). It can be seen that PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE exhibited no obvious current response in the presence of AA (5 times concentration). According to the experimental results, PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE exhibited good anti-interference in the presence of AA.
Electrochemical sensing application of AuNPs/PANI/nMnOOH.—Figures 8A and 8B show the CV curves of the GCE (a, a’), MnOOH nanonet/GCE (b, b’), PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE (c, c’), and AuNPs/PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE (d, d’) systems in the absence (a–d) and presence (a’–d’) of 10 mM AA in 0.1 M PBS (pH = 7.2). These results demonstrate that GCE exhibits almost no electrochemical
Table I. Comparison of several typical DA sensors.
Sensors Linear range (mM) LOD(μM) Refs.

N-graphene 0.0005–0.17 0.25 39 Au-rGO 0.0068–0.041 1.4 40
MCNTs/PPy 0.0006–0.1 0.06 41 ZnO-rGO 0.003–0.33 1.08 42

) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 132.174.251.90Downloaded on 2019-07-20 to IP
response in the absence of AA (Figure 8A-a). After adding 10 mM of AA, a weak signal appeared (Figure 8A-a’) at approximately 0.25 V with a current height of 4 μA. MnOOH/GCE showed a larger current response than the GCE after 10 mM of AA were added (Figure 8Ab’). This peak was detected at 0.45 V with a current height of approximately 16 μA. In contrast to MnOOH/GCE, PANI/MnOOH/GCE exhibited no obvious current response after 10 mM of AA were added (Figure 8B-c’). The constructed AuNPs/PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE system showed the largest current response at 0.3 V with a current peak of 26 μA in the presence of 10 mM of AA (Figure 8B-d’). This result indicates that AuNPs/PANI/n-MnOOH is catalytically active for the electrooxidation of AA. In addition, AuNPs/PANI/n-MnOOH composites with different amounts of AuNPs were used for fabrication of electrochemical sensing system respectively (Figure S5). According to the experimental results, when 50mL Au colloid were used, the obtained AuNPs/PANI/n-MnOOH exhibited best catalytic property. It may be due to the following reasons: when 20mL Au colloid were used, AuNPs were too few; When 80mL Au colloid were used, too many AuNPs will be aggregated and the catalytic property of AuNPs/PANI/n-MnOOH will be decreased.
The CV curves of AuNPs/PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE were analyzed as a function of AA concentration (Figure 8C). The peak current of the modified electrode increased with increasing AA concentration in a linear fashion (Figure 8D). Figure 8E shows the amperometric response of AuNPs/PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE in 0.1 M of PBS (pH = 7.2) at an initial potential of 0.3 V. The AuNPs/PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE electrode displayed good current responses when different concentrations of AA were added. Additionally, the modified electrode exhibited a broad linear detection range of 0.3–77.8 mM (Figure 8F). The linear regression equation was determined to be I(μA) = 0.38C(mM) + 0.39 with an estimated detection limit of 0.1 μM.
Comparing the prepared AuNPs/PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE to several reported AA electrochemical sensors (Table II), AuNPs/PANI/nMnOOH/GCE exhibits a relatively low detection limit and broad linear range. These properties can be rationalized by the homogeneous morphology of the AuNPs on the surface of PANI/n-MnOOH, which provides a good platform for AA catalysis as well as the net-like structure, which provides more catalytically active sites. Finally, the conductivity
of the prepared electrode is likely enhanced by the combination of Au and PANI. Then, the stability and reproducibility of Au NPs/PANI/nMnOOH/GCE have been researched, and the results have been shown in Figure S6 and Table S2. It can be seen that the modified electrode exhibited good stability and reproducibility (Supporting information).
Real sample analysis.—The modified PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE and Au NPs/PANI/n-MnOOH/GCE were applied to determine DA in dopamine hydrochloride injection and AA in Vitamin C injection, respectively. Different amounts of standard samples were injected in samples respectively. At last, i-t was used for electrochemical sensing detection. The results were summarized in Table III, indicating the great potential application of modified electrodes for determination of AA and DA in real samples.
